Court_Ruling: The Citizenship Judge's decision was unreasonable
Defendant_Behavior: Applied strict interpretation of Pourghasemi test focusing on physical presence
Grounds_for_Claim: Denial based solely on physical presence despite strong Canadian ties
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence, established residence, centralized mode of existence
Procedural_Issue: Remittal to a different Citizenship Judge for re-determination
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, educational and employment history in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Duration of absence, nature of activities abroad, integration into Canadian society
Relief_Sought: Granting of citizenship upon proper assessment
Governing_Rule: One of three tests: Pourghasemi, Papadogiorgakis, or Koo
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider alternative residency tests despite evidence of integration
Harm_Assessment: Unfair denial of citizenship due to rigid application of test
Cause_Description: Citizenship application denied for not meeting residency requirement under Pourghasemi test
Evidence_Handling: Considered duration of absence but overlooked integration factors
Legal_Provision_Violated: paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act (as interpreted)
Evidence_Issues: Incomplete assessment of residency through narrow test
